answers: Kashmir [accept Jammu and Kashmir; accept Azad Kashmir]
Maoism [prompt on Marxism or Leninism or Marxism-Leninism or communism]
parts: Roy has long supported the self-determination of this northernmost-region of India, control over which has been disputed with Pakistan since independence.
Roy criticized the government for taking military action against the Naxalites, who are followers of this ideology. The essays On Contradiction and On Practice are foundational to this ideology.

Roy opposed the Sardar Sarovar Dam because it was being built on the land of people denoted by this term, which collectively refers to Indian minority groups who are considered indigenous to their respective regions.

answers: Kazan [accept Kazan Khanate or Kazan Cathedral]
parts: The pioneering explorer of Siberia, Yermak, was a hetman of these semi-nomadic, warlike Slavic people. Many of them lived on the banks of the Don river.
The expansion was facilitated by Ivan the Terrible's conquest of this Tatar city, which he celebrated by building a cathedral in Moscow named for it. Today, this city is the capital of Tatarstan.

To solidify its control of Siberia, as well as later Alaska, Russia built many examples of these buildings known as ostrogi. These small forts, which are similar to pillboxes, contain small holes to fire weapons from.

answers: Gabriela Mistral [or Lucila Godoy Alcayaga] (Those are the Sonnets of Death.)
Chile [or Republic of Chile; or República de Chile]
parts: Name this author of the collections Desolación and Tala, who lamented the suicide of Romelio Ureta ("roh-MEH-lee-oh oo-REH-tah") in a prize-winning sequence of modernist sonnets.
Mistral was from this South American country, which also produced the author of Canto General ("KAHN-toh heh-neh-RAHL"), Pablo Neruda.

Mistral dedicated her "Poema del hijo" ("poh-EH-mah del EE-hoh") to this friend of hers. The lines "You want me like dawn / You want me made of sea-foam" open this Argentine author's poem "You Want Me White".

answers: brood parasitism [accept brood parasites; prompt on parasitism or parasites]
mimicry [accept egg mimicry; accept aggressive mimicry or Peckhamian mimicry; accept Batesian mimicry]
parts: Name this reproductive strategy seen in many birds, in which one organism places its eggs in another species's nest, so the other species will raise their young.

The eggs of brood parasites often resemble those of their hosts, an example of this phenomenon. In another example, cuckoos scare off other birds to lay eggs in their nests by looking like sparrowhawks.
In cuckoos, genetic and evolutionary factors cause the creation of these lineages, which only place their eggs in the nest of a specific other species.

answers: queer [or queering; accept New Queer Cinema; accept Flaming Classics: Queering the Film Canon]
parts: Give this adjective. Its verb form appears in the title of a 2000 Alexander Doty book titled for "Flaming Classics" of the film canon.

Rich credits this 1990 documentary by Jeannie Livingston with introducing a wide popular audience to queer cinema. This film explores New York City drag culture through a competition held by the title artist, surnamed Duprée.
Rich later identified this 2005 Ang Lee film as changing the direction of New Queer Cinema. It follows the relationship between two cattle herders in 1960s Wyoming.
Name this quantity which, for anisotropic media, is a tensor relating the displacement and electric fields. The "relative" value of this quantity is the dielectric constant.
The standard electric permittivity of this medium is 8.85 times 10 to the negative 12th Farads per meter.
Because the complex permittivity is analytic on the upper half plane, one can use these integral identities to relate the complex permittivity's real and imaginary parts.

answers: Tanabata [prompt on star festival or festival of stars, etc. or hoshi matsuri; do not accept or prompt on "Qīxī" or "Chilseok"]
the Cowherd AND the Weaver Girl [or Niúláng AND Zhīnǚ; or Hikoboshi AND Orihime; or Kengyuusei AND Shokujosei; or Gyuurou AND Shokujo; accept answers in either order]
Milky Way [or Amanogawa; or Gingakei; or Yínhéxì; or Tiānhé; or Xīnghé; or Tiānhàn]
parts: Name this holiday in which paper wish tags are hung on bamboo stalks. Since this festival absorbed one in which shrine maidens wove sacred cloths, it's named for a type of loom.
Tanabata celebrates a story of Chinese origin in which these two people reunite once per year, connected by a bridge of magpies. You may give their English, Japanese, or Chinese names.
The mythical bridge of magpies crosses this celestial object, which many people conceived of as a river in the sky.

answers: Yunior de las Casas [accept either underlined portion]
parts: Name this final story of the collection This is How You Lose Her. Its narrator tries to put his life back together after the end of a relationship in which he was unfaithful for six years.

This personification of machismo is the protagonist of "The Cheater's Guide to Love". He narrates the novel The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao, in which he advises the protagonist to start lifting weights.
Both "The Cheater's Guide to Love" and The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao are by this Dominican-American author.

answers: lithic [accept Neolithic age; accept Lithic stage]
pit-houses [accept sunken featured buildings or SFBs; accept grubhouses, grubenhauser, or grubhuts]
parts: Give this word from the Greek for "stone". When prefixed by "neo-," it denotes the age when agricultural communities began to form.

Both pre-ceramic Andean cultures and this one, considered ancestral to many Native American cultures, existed in the Lithic stage. Not to be confused with a Dark Age king, it is best known for its distinct arrowheads.
Clovis and pre-ceramic Andean cultures both built these dwellings, which are named because their floors are slightly dug into the earth. They were common among ancient peoples of New Mexico.
Name this character from a Tennyson poem, depicted with long, flowy hair in that William Holman Hunt painting. A John William Waterhouse painting depicts this woman riding on a black barge.
As exemplified by Hunt's Lady of Shalott, many members of this group admired Tennyson's works. These British Romantics sought to return to a style present before a namesake Italian artist.
Tennyson asked this photographer to create illustrations for his collection Idylls of the King. She took close-ups of many Victorians such as John Herschel.

answers: Koxinga [or Zheng Chenggong, Prince of Yanping]
parts: Resentment towards the succeeding Qing ("ching") dynasty came from the fact that their emperors were of this ethnicity. Their namesake region of China was turned into a Japanese puppet state during World War II.
This warlord established the Kingdom of Tungning ("toong-neeng") in his attempts to restore the Ming dynasty. The Kangxi emperor forced people to move inland to cut off this man's supplies.

The Qianlong ("ch'yen-long") Emperor quelled an uprising by this secret society, of which many Ming loyalists were members. The herbalist Wang Lun sparked the regrowth of this society in the 18th century.
Name this novel by Emily Brontë whose narrator, Nelly Dean, is paralleled by Fumiko Tsuchiya in Mizamura's novel.

In A True Novel, the central role of the Oiwake ("oh-ee-wah-keh") villa mirrors the central role of this country estate of the Linton family in Wuthering Heights, which is eventually acquired by Heathcliff.

Unlike Wuthering Heights, Mizamura's A True Novel has a prologue set in this city, though most of the novel is set in Tokyo and the countryside. Takashi returns to Tokyo after living in this city at the beginning of Kenzaburo Oe's novel The Silent Cry.
Astronaut Cady Coleman has performed solos on multiple variants of this high, transverse woodwind instrument while aboard the International Space Station, including a wooden Irish one.

This avant-garde German composer called for a string quartet to play aboard four separate helicopters in his "Helicopter String Quartet," which plays third scene of his opera Mittwoch aus Licht ("MEET-vokh aus leesht").

Though it is unfortunately played on Earth, the score of this Dadaist composition by George Antheil ("zhorzh on-TAYL") calls for three airplane propellers, as well as electric bells and player pianos.

answers: antiferromagnetism [do not accept or prompt on "ferromagnetism"]
Curie temperature [accept Pierre Curie or Marie Curie]
parts: Name this property which causes a coupling between iron[III] and oxygen in hemoglobin.
A spin-polarized "bridging" one of these molecules can mediate antiferromagnetic coupling between two metals. EDTA is a hexadentate one of these molecules.

The disappearance of antiferromagnetism above the Neel temperature is analogous to the disappearance of ferromagnetism above this temperature, which is named for the husband of the only person to win Nobel prizes in both physics and chemistry.

answers: doctor [or médecin; accept Doctor Cupid, or The Flying Doctor, or The Doctor in Spite of Himself, or L'Amour médecin, or Le Médecin volant, or Le Médecin malgré lui]
The Imaginary Cuckold [or Le Cocu imaginaire]
parts: Give this profession. In another play, Sganarelle is a woodcutter who inadvertently takes up this title profession after helping a different Lucinde.
This French author of Tartuffe played Sganarelle in many performances of those plays, which he wrote.

In this other Molière play, Sganarelle is falsely convinced that his wife is unfaithful, so he advises the audience to "never believe anything". The greedy Gorgibus plans to marry off his daughter in this play.

answers: Rashi [or Shlomo Yitzchaki; or Salomon Isaacides; prompt on Salomon de Troyes; prompt on Rabbi Shlomo or Rabbi Salomon]
parts: Name this medieval rabbi from Troyes ("TRWAH") who wrote the first full Talmud commentary and a major commentary on the Tanakh. Commentaries on this man's commentaries are called Tosafot.
Rashi's commentary on this part of the Tanakh was one of his most influential works and the first Hebrew book to be printed; it's often studied to review this text's weekly portion.
When reviewing the Torah portion, the corresponding part of Rashi's commentary may uniquely be read in place of the required reading from this Aramaic translation of the Torah.

answers: capital [accept Capital and Ideology or Capital in the 21st Century]
property rights [or properties; prompt on rights or ownership rights]
parts: Name this concept which titles that book by Thomas Piketty, as well as Piketty's best-known book. With land and labor, it is one of three major factors of production.
This economist has criticized Piketty for ignoring "dead capital" in the informal sector, which he analyzed in The Mystery of Capital.

To bring "dead capital" into the open, De Soto has proposed a blockchain to formalize these concepts in third-world countries. The Coase theorem suggests that externalities will be resolved if these concepts are well-defined.

answers: More [accept Henry More or Thomas More]
kabbalah [or kabbalistic thought; prompt on Jewish mysticism or Judaism]
parts: Name this Cambridge Platonist, best known for her treatise The Principles of the Most Ancient and Modern Philosophy.
Conway's treatise partly refutes an English philosopher with this surname who taught her and summarized his own views in his Divine Dialogues. Another philosopher with this surname wrote Utopia.

Conway extensively studied the version of this system of thought developed by Isaac Luria. Pico della Mirandola based his exegesis ("ex-EH-jeh-sis") of Genesis on this system's pardes ("par-DES") tradition.

answers: Alien and Sedition Acts [prompt on partial answers]
friends AND enemies [accept Alien Friends Act AND Alien Enemies Act]
parts: This group of four laws passed in 1798 included one criminalizing speech against the government.

Among the Alien Acts were laws named for these two sorts of people -- one permitting deportation of citizens of countries at war with the US, the other permitting deportation of aliens accused of plotting against the US. Name both.

This other law criminalizes negotiations by unauthorized citizens with foreign governments. Nobody has ever been convicted of violating it, though Obama-era officials considered charging Michael Flynn under it.

answers: interpolation [accept word forms such as interpolating]
parts: Name this operation which, for a function f(x) ("f of x"), is defined as (read slowly) the integral from minus infinity to infinity of f(x), times e raised to the minus 2 pi i s x, times dx.

For a Discrete Fourier Transform of length L ("ell"), the DFT performs this operation on the DTFT at the points 2π/L ("two-pi-over-ell"). This general task uses several known points of a function on an interval to approximate the function within the interval.
Multiplying the DFTs of two functions in the frequency domain is equivalent to performing this operation in the time domain.
